subject: Re: [junit] Documenting test cases

messageBody:
Kevin Lawrence wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > David Plass wrote:
> >
> >
> >>I agree that the 'assertTrue' is redundant, but it tells the reader
> >>(reviewer) that I know what I'm doing without my writing a comment.
> >>My fingers already know how to type that pattern below.
> >
> >
> > It's a question of taste whether assertTrue(true) is easier to read than
> > a blank line. It depends how comfortable you are with the idea that if a
> > test falls through, it passes.
>
> I try to make a habit of putting user-friendly messages in exceptions in
> case the message makes it all the way out to the user or to a log. To
> this end, I almost always check the message in a test. Here's a test
> that I wrote about 20 minutes ago :
>
>
> public void testFactoryThrowsException() throws Exception {
> factory.setProperty("minValue", new Integer(6));
> factory.setProperty("maxValue", new Integer(5));
>
> try {
> tester.generateSnapshots(factory);
> }
> catch (FactoryTestException exception) {
> assertEquals("Factory test for [My Factory] failed",
>
> exception.getMessage());
> assertEquals("minimum exceeds maximum",
> exception.getCause().getMessage());
> }
> }
>
> An added bonus of this is that if a FactoryTestException is thrown from
> somewhere other than where I was expecting it, the test will fail.
>
> It also documents the behavior for the caller.

I like this technique; however, I'm worried about checking English
messages in such a test. I would sooner write this test:

public void testFactoryThrowsException() throws Exception {
factory.setProperty("minValue", new Integer(6));
factory.setProperty("maxValue", new Integer(5));

try {
tester.generateSnapshots(factory);
}
catch (FactoryTestException exception) {
assertEquals("factory.test.failed",
exception.getUserMessage().getKey());

assertEquals(new MinimumExceedsMaximumException(),
exception.getCause());
}
}

In other words, I check user message keys, rather than message text; and
I ask the exception object whether it's the right object, rather than
checking message text.

I find these kinds of text-based assertions hyperactive (per Phlip's
definition), and therefore refactoring-unfriendly.
